nodes.bodyText: I wouldn't.  I don't think the performance gain is worth the potential confusion if someone does something like try to accumulate duplicate sets during the traversal.
This should be private, protected, or marked visiblefortesting.
Sounds good. Done
I'm not super happy about that, it makes it less clear if downstream tools are meant to override it.

Maybe I'm being dense, but couldn't you initialize this in place when you define the variable and not need to do it here?  That would avoid the need for overriding onStartup.  If you can't instantiate a DuplicateSet and set the ID at the same time, I would just change duplicate set.  It would probably be better though if instead of exposing a magic number, DuplicateSet had a function like isEmpty() that would answer the question of if a read has been added to it yet.
Good points. Done.
Is there any way to tell if the file is sorted in the correct way or not?  It would be good to check that it is somehow.
You could do something silly like using a bloom filter to track already seen molecules ID's and warn if you see a surplus of collisions.

I would check if the bam have any sorting subkeys specified, it's a thing Nil's and Tim wanted to add to the spec so they might be outputting the.  I don't think htsjdk knows about them yet but if it exists in the bams it would be a good reason to make htsjdk aware of it.
Bam header has SO:unsorted.
Added a check to ensure that the molecular ID is monotonically increasing and that the tag exists. They should catch it if the input bam is not sorted as required—is that good enough?
Yeah, that sounds great.
final
Done
removed variable
We're trying to eliminate the use of File wherever possible,  since its limiting, and rely the more general GATKPathSpecifier.
Done
@cmnbroad should I avoid createTempFile() in test classes as well? It creates a File object.
@takutosato No - using createTempFile  and File in tests is fine for now. Thanks.
Awesome, thanks!
If you use my GATKPathSpecifier suggestion above, you can just call .toPath() on the GATKPathSpecifier instance here.
Pre-sorted = false means this will resort the output I believe.  Is that what you want?

.toPath -> done.
Hmmm. That's not what I want. But I don't think it sorts the output. Will investigate.
It probably doesn't sort it if the sort order is listed as "unsorted"

Make this final so downstream tools don't accidentally think they have to override it.  Modify the javadoc to explain that this shouldn't be called by the user and is only public because of prior constraints and point to the new apply they have to implement.
done*3
This needs javadoc
done
This also needs javadoc explaining what it does and if you need to override it.
The naming is ok, but it might be better as something like duplicateSetHasValidInterval to make it clear what it's checking.
done*2. The idea is that the subclass can override it this to specify its own criteria for filtering a duplicate set, and I think "reject" is a clearer verb than "filter"
Is this a normal thing that happens or an error condition?
This was a vestige of an earlier bug but I think I can safely remove the logging
Lets extract this boolean as variable the first time we compute it.  That way if someone edits the code we can't get a mismatching case between the warning and the return value.
rewritten
lets see if we can avoid this.  I think we can.
Yes I'm going to try. Uno momento.
Hmn, I think returning null is ok because some tools might want to be able to process empty files without exploding.  Just document clearly that it can return null.
method removed
extract this to a variable instead of calling it twice
done
You could change this expression to be something like currentDuplicateSet.moleculeIdsMatch(read) which might read better.

This seems like a reasonable thing to add to the engine, but it needs documentation and possibly a rename.  Maybe finalizeTraversal would make sense?  Make it clear that it's different from onTraversalSuccess because it's meant to be implemented by framework classes, not actual tools.
@droazen Any thoughts on this?  The other option would be to override traverse in the subclass which is always awkward if unnecessary.
renamed to finalizeTraversal and made it final in DuplicateSetWalker.
I said above, but this needs documentation
done
Reference SAMTag.RX.name() here instead of totally redefining it from scratch.  It's ok to still assign it to a named constant since RX.name() isn't super helpful..
private is the standard for this for some reason.

Split once and save the array into a variable.
Utils.split(String, char) is substantially faster for non-regex splitting like this.
Could you fix UMI.getUMI() while you're at it?  It does the same wasteful thing.    You might consider using that method as well to avoid reimplementing this.
In fact, why not give UMI a string constructor, then make the argument a UMI, and just use UMI.equalsModuloOrder(). It would save reimplementing a bunch of stuff.
Should we validate that constraint somewhere?  @cmnbroad is there a way to do validation of the arguments in a readfilter?
Nothing built it. Maybe UMI should have a String constructor that does the splitting/parsing and then this arg can be typed as a UMI.
This would be faster if you reworked it to check umi.equals(readUmi) first before deconstructing the string.  In any case, there's no need to rebuild readUMI, only the reversed order one.
dead code.  Do you want to allow many UMIs?
Needs class javadoc.
final final
save the array instead of splitting twice, mentioned above
Should these things have getters?
this seems broken
Why have this and the constructor?
This is unused.
This should be javadoc.
This should also be javadoc
Is this post error correction?
Javadoc
This is redundant since you sorted them already, just return umiSmall + umiLong, or better yet just save the combination.
This class has lots of unused/untested stuff that probably should be used / tested.  The umi logic should be implemented here and called from the filter.
typo?  tumor subclones
done
I would probably give this a more descriptive name.  Maybe "fraction-to-keep"?
nodes.diffHunk:
@@ -0,0 +1,114 @@
+package org.broadinstitute.hellbender.tools.walkers.consensus;
+
+import org.apache.commons.math3.random.RandomGenerator;
+import org.apache.commons.math3.random.RandomGeneratorFactory;
+import org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.Argument;
+import org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.CommandLineProgramProperties;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.cmdline.StandardArgumentDefinitions;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.DuplicateSetWalker;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.FeatureContext;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.ReferenceContext;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.tools.walkers.mutect.consensus.DuplicateSet;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.utils.io.IOUtils;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.utils.read.SAMFileGATKReadWriter;
+import picard.cmdline.programgroups.ReadDataManipulationProgramGroup;
+
+import java.io.File;
+import java.util.List;
+import java.util.Random;
+
+@CommandLineProgramProperties(
+        summary = "Discard a set fraction of duplicate sets from a UMI-grouped ba",
+        oneLineSummary = "Discard a set fraction of duplicate sets from a UMI-grouped bam",
+        programGroup = ReadDataManipulationProgramGroup.class
+)
+/**
+ * Given a bam grouped by the same unique molecular identifier (UMI), this tool drops a fraction of duplicate sets and returns a new bam.
+ * A duplicate set refers to a group of reads whose fragments start at and end at the same coordinate and share the same UMI.
+ *
+ * The input bam must have been sorted by UMI using FGBio GroupReadsByUmi (http://fulcrumgenomics.github.io/fgbio/tools/latest/GroupReadsByUmi.html).
+ *
+ * Use this tool to create, for instance, an insilico mixture of duplex-sequenced samples to simulate tumor subclone.
+ * Suppose you wish to simulate a tumor sample in which 5% cells share a common set of somatic mutations
+ * in addition to ones common to the entire cell population.
+ *
+ * If you randomly drop 5% of reads in sample A and 95% of reads in sample B and merge the reduced bams,
+ * the resulting mixture skews the family-size distribution to the left. Here the family size refers to the
+ * number of sequenced duplicate reads that share the same UMI.
+ *
+ * To see this, take a cancer sample, in which 5% of cells (i.e. a subclone) share a unique set of somatic mutations,
+ * that was processed with duplex-UMIs (i.e. UMIs on both adapters) and high rounds of PCR. Suppose we have the sequence-ready
+ * libraries of this sample attached to and amplified on the flowcell. Now, sort the flowcell lawn such that the
+ * 5% subclone moves near the top of the flowcell. This subclone must have the same family-size distribution as
+ * the rest of the flowcell, at about 5% of the library complexity compared to the entire flowcell.
+ *
+ * Now imagine replacing this subclone with 5% of the *entire* flowcell from another sample prepared and sequenced similarly.
+ * The library complexity of these "graft" reads is higher than that of the original, and, consequently, with other parameters
+ * such as the number of PCR cycles and sequencing depth fixed, its family distribution would be skewed left---that is, the family size
+ * would be smaller than it should be.
+ *
+ * This tool address the above problem by dropping a set fraction of _duplicate sets_, rather than reads, at random.
+ * Implicit in this approach is that a read and its mate are dropped or retained together.
+ * While trivial when the input bam is sorted by UMI and query name, this is far from trivial when one attempts
+ * to downsample reads naively with a tool like {@link PrintReads}.
+ *
+ **/
+public class DownsampleByDuplicateSet extends DuplicateSetWalker {
+    @Argument(fullName = StandardArgumentDefinitions.OUTPUT_LONG_NAME, shortName = StandardArgumentDefinitions.OUTPUT_SHORT_NAME, doc = "")
+    public File outputBam;
+
+    @Argument(fullName = "DS", doc = "This fraction of duplicate sets in the input bam will be retained")

nodes.bodyText: You should add bounds to this, i.e. minValue = 0.0 maxValue = 1.0

nodes.bodyText: I don't think these fields should be static.
done
This is unnecessary because the walker bases are obligated to NOT implement this.  It's fine to do it anyway though.
removed
Why use the apache3 RandomNumberGenerator and not the built in Random?  If there's no good reason I would just use the java builtin.  I might add a comment if there is a reason to use the apache one.
No reason, just copied and pasted from another tool. Happy to use Random instead.
This should also be closed in closeTool() and you should check for null before doing so there.
Done
If this is experimental I would make the argument that enables it @Advanced
I'm confused about this.  I thought  reads were only added if they had the same molecularID?

Ooh, there is a difference between the String molecular id's and the int molecular ids.  I would rename stuff because it's confusing as hell.  Maybe something like "getMolecularIdNumber" vs "getCompleteMolecularIds"?

Exactly. Two reads can have the same molecular number, which means they come from the same molecule, but they can come from the different strands.
I'm going to extract a class for ID, with members ID number (e.g. 1,2,...) and strand (A/B) etc to make this clear
Do you have to take things like secondary/supplementary alignments into account here?
I believe those are filtered by the upstream fgbio tool

Needs javadoc.  This might cause confusion with the existing DuplicateSet from htsjdk.  I don't know if there's a slightly more descriptive name that could be used?  If you think DuplicateSet is the right name then some confusion is ok though.
Renamed to ReadSetWithSharedUMI tentatively. Javadoc written.
I think this is standard in the sam spec now.  ReferenceSamTags.MI.name()
Super
I'm confused about this, you expose -1 as a constant elsewhere, can all of that be handled internally instead?
This is never actually used.
Removed
This should implement Locatable.
Done
this can be final and initialized here.
You could keep an internal simple interval  / locatable if you didn't want 3 fields.  It's fine to have 3 though if you think that's easier.
This is never set or used
This isn't used either and it's only kind of set.
This comment needs addressing.
javadoc
If your second constructor starts with the same code as the first constructor it's better to just do this();
done
This seems like it should be private.
done
typo in Inconsisntent.
ooops
split these onto 2 lines.
You probably want to wrap this in an UnmodifiableList to prevent someone from doing something wacky with the output that breaks assumptions about the duplicate set.
done
javadoc
typo moledule
I think this method should probably be removed.  Is there a use case for changing the molecule ID after it's already set?  Seems dangerous.
That's true, removed
typo moledule
Similarly, this should probably be removed.
done

Is there ever a reason for allowing improper reads in the set?  It seems like this would better if it threw when an incorrect read was added.  That way you never have to check that the set is valid, it just is...
True, done
I'm again confused about the use of invalid duplicate sets with different molecules.  Seems like bad news.
Yes, the way the code is written, when this method returns false it the tool exists with error. I'm going to move that check to the beginning of this method to make that clear.
If you are keeping an internal simple interval instead of separate values you could use interval.spanWith(read) instead of this logic.
It seems like there will be problems if you have reads from different contigs.  I assume that's possible since they are aligned separately?
Much cleaner with spanWith. Now checks that the incoming read has the same contig.
javadoc
doc
doc
unnecessary if this is locatable.

This seems strange.  If you're computing intervals correctly you should never get an invalid one UNLESS you're mixing different contigs, in which case you probably want to test that more aggressively so that you don't sometimes get them by accident.
True. Removed.
javadoc, confusing why we want this

Ok, I understand this now... you need clear javadoc and probably to rename this method since it's very strange that getMolecularID on 2 reads can produce the same result but getMolecularIDs then has 2 values.
Lets copy this to our bucket so we have our own copy and it can't be deleted out from under us
needs to be marked with groups="cloud"
Specifying the program name should be unnecessary, it should automatic that.
Should this test test something?
this needs to be a temp file
This is unused and adds complication, lets remove it.
done
declare this in a try-with-resources block
done
declare datasources in a try-with-resources
use the constant you defined
done
Can you add a test that shows that DS = 0.0 produces an empty file?
Should the doc include an example usage?

@@ -0,0 +1,114 @@
+package org.broadinstitute.hellbender.tools.walkers.consensus;
+
+import org.apache.commons.math3.random.RandomGenerator;
+import org.apache.commons.math3.random.RandomGeneratorFactory;
+import org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.Argument;
+import org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.CommandLineProgramProperties;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.cmdline.StandardArgumentDefinitions;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.DuplicateSetWalker;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.FeatureContext;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.ReferenceContext;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.tools.walkers.mutect.consensus.DuplicateSet;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.utils.io.IOUtils;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.utils.read.SAMFileGATKReadWriter;
+import picard.cmdline.programgroups.ReadDataManipulationProgramGroup;
+
+import java.io.File;
+import java.util.List;
+import java.util.Random;
+
+@CommandLineProgramProperties(
+        summary = "Discard a set fraction of duplicate sets from a UMI-grouped ba",
+        oneLineSummary = "Discard a set fraction of duplicate sets from a UMI-grouped bam",
+        programGroup = ReadDataManipulationProgramGroup.class
+)
+/**
+ * Given a bam grouped by the same unique molecular identifier (UMI), this tool drops a fraction of duplicate sets and returns a new bam.
+ * A duplicate set refers to a group of reads whose fragments start at and end at the same coordinate and share the same UMI.
+ *
+ * The input bam must have been sorted by UMI using FGBio GroupReadsByUmi (http://fulcrumgenomics.github.io/fgbio/tools/latest/GroupReadsByUmi.html).
+ *
+ * Use this tool to create, for instance, an insilico mixture of duplex-sequenced samples to simulate tumor subclone.
+ * Suppose you wish to simulate a tumor sample in which 5% cells share a common set of somatic mutations
+ * in addition to ones common to the entire cell population.
+ *
+ * If you randomly drop 5% of reads in sample A and 95% of reads in sample B and merge the reduced bams,
+ * the resulting mixture skews the family-size distribution to the left. Here the family size refers to the
+ * number of sequenced duplicate reads that share the same UMI.
+ *
+ * To see this, take a cancer sample, in which 5% of cells (i.e. a subclone) share a unique set of somatic mutations,
+ * that was processed with duplex-UMIs (i.e. UMIs on both adapters) and high rounds of PCR. Suppose we have the sequence-ready
+ * libraries of this sample attached to and amplified on the flowcell. Now, sort the flowcell lawn such that the
+ * 5% subclone moves near the top of the flowcell. This subclone must have the same family-size distribution as
+ * the rest of the flowcell, at about 5% of the library complexity compared to the entire flowcell.
+ *
+ * Now imagine replacing this subclone with 5% of the *entire* flowcell from another sample prepared and sequenced similarly.
+ * The library complexity of these "graft" reads is higher than that of the original, and, consequently, with other parameters
+ * such as the number of PCR cycles and sequencing depth fixed, its family distribution would be skewed left---that is, the family size
+ * would be smaller than it should be.
+ *
+ * This tool address the above problem by dropping a set fraction of _duplicate sets_, rather than reads, at random.
+ * Implicit in this approach is that a read and its mate are dropped or retained together.
+ * While trivial when the input bam is sorted by UMI and query name, this is far from trivial when one attempts
+ * to downsample reads naively with a tool like {@link PrintReads}.

nodes.bodyText: Example usage added.
nodes.diffHunk:

+ *

+ * that was processed with duplex-UMIs (i.e. UMIs on both adapters) and high rounds of PCR. Suppose we have the sequence-ready
+ * libraries of this sample attached to and amplified on the flowcell. Now, sort the flowcell lawn such that the
+ * 5% subclone moves near the top of the flowcell. This subclone must have the same family-size distribution as
+ * the rest of the flowcell, at about 5% of the library complexity compared to the entire flowcell.
+ *
+ * Now imagine replacing this subclone with 5% of the *entire* flowcell from another sample prepared and sequenced similarly.
+ * The library complexity of these "graft" reads is higher than that of the original, and, consequently, with other parameters
+ * such as the number of PCR cycles and sequencing depth fixed, its family distribution would be skewed left---that is, the family size
+ * would be smaller than it should be.
+ *
+ * This tool address the above problem by dropping a set fraction of _duplicate sets_, rather than reads, at random.
+ * Implicit in this approach is that a read and its mate are dropped or retained together.
+ * While trivial when the input bam is sorted by UMI and query name, this is far from trivial when one attempts
+ * to downsample reads naively with a tool like {@link PrintReads}.

I misread this at first as the "read sets containing both strands will be kept ONLY if this is set to a positive number"
Ah I went back and forth about this and I clearly chose wrong. done.
You can add a minValue = 0 here to keep it positive.
done
I would add a minValue to the argument to make sure it's positive.

I like to put the exclusive conditions in an else block to make it clear that none of the options above fall down into this, but that's a style point that some people disagree with.
Yea I didn't like the way the if else blocks looked so I did it this way, hope that's ok.
Is there a todo to make this smarter in the future or is % a good enough check?
I think this is good enough for now
This is a bit inconsistent with the rest of the framework.  Lets consider changing this in a future refactor.

boy scout rule done

+package org.broadinstitute.hellbender.tools.walkers.consensus;
+
+import org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.Argument;
+import org.broadinstitute.barclay.argparser.CommandLineProgramProperties;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.cmdline.StandardArgumentDefinitions;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.DuplicateSetWalker;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.FeatureContext;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.GATKPathSpecifier;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.engine.ReferenceContext;
+import org.broadinstitute.hellbender.utils.read.SAMFileGATKReadWriter;
+import picard.cmdline.programgroups.ReadDataManipulationProgramGroup;
+
+import java.util.Random;
+
+@CommandLineProgramProperties(
+        summary = "Discard a set fraction of duplicate sets from a UMI-grouped bam",
+        oneLineSummary = "Discard a set fraction of duplicate sets from a UMI-grouped bam",
+        programGroup = ReadDataManipulationProgramGroup.class
+)
+/**
+ * Given a bam grouped by the same unique molecular identifier (UMI), this tool drops a specified fraction of duplicate sets and returns a new bam.
+ * A duplicate set refers to a group of reads whose fragments start and end at the same genomic coordinate _and_ share the same UMI.
+ *
+ * The input bam must first be sorted by UMI using FGBio GroupReadsByUmi (http://fulcrumgenomics.github.io/fgbio/tools/latest/GroupReadsByUmi.html).
+ *
+ * Use this tool to create, for instance, an insilico mixture of duplex-sequenced samples to simulate tumor subclones.
+ *
+ * Suppose you wish to simulate a tumor sample in which 5% cells share a common set of somatic mutations
+ * in addition to ones common to the entire cell population.
+ *
+ * If you randomly drop 5% of reads in sample A and 95% of reads in sample B and merge the reduced bams,
+ * the resulting mixture skews the family-size distribution to the left. Here the family size refers to the
+ * number of sequenced duplicate reads that share the same UMI.
+ *
+ * To see this, take a cancer sample, in which 5% of cells share a unique set of somatic mutations,
+ * that was processed with duplex-UMIs (i.e. UMIs on both adapters) and high rounds of PCR. Suppose we have the sequence-ready
+ * libraries of this sample attached to and amplified on the flowcell. Now, sort the flowcell lawn such that the reads from the above
+ * 5% of the cell population moves near the top of the flowcell. This population must have the same family-size distribution as
+ * the rest of the flowcell, at about 5% of the library complexity compared to the entire flowcell.
+ *
+ * Now imagine replacing this population with 5% ramdonly chosen from the *entire* flowcell of another sample that was prepared and sequenced similarly.
+ * The library complexity of these "graft" reads is higher than that of the original, and, consequently, with other parameters
+ * such as the number of PCR cycles and sequencing depth fixed, its family distribution would be skewed left---that is, the family size
+ * would be smaller than it should be.
+ *
+ * This tool will help address the above problem by dropping a set fraction of _molecules_, or duplicate sets, rather than reads, at random.
+ *
+ * Example Usage:
+ *
+ * Keep 95 percent of the molecules.
+ *
+ * gatk DownsampleByDuplicateSet \ \
+ * -I umiGrouped.bam \
+ * --fraction-to-keep 0.95 \
+ * -O umiGrouped_0.95.bam
+ **/
+public class DownsampleByDuplicateSet extends DuplicateSetWalker {
+    @Argument(fullName = StandardArgumentDefinitions.OUTPUT_LONG_NAME, shortName = StandardArgumentDefinitions.OUTPUT_SHORT_NAME, doc = "")
+    public GATKPathSpecifier outputBam;
+
+    public static final String FRACTION_TO_KEEP_NAME = "fraction-to-keep";
+    @Argument(fullName = FRACTION_TO_KEEP_NAME, doc = "This fraction of molecules in the input bam will be retained", minValue = 0.0, maxValue = 1.0)
+    public double fractionToKeep;
+
+    private static final int RANDOM_SEED = 142;
+    private Random rng;
+    private int numDuplicateReadSets;
+    private int numReads;
+    private SAMFileGATKReadWriter outputWriter;
+
+    @Override
+    public void onTraversalStart() {
+        rng = new Random(RANDOM_SEED);
